data.title: Woman journalist saves girl from man asking for 'dirty' photo on flight
data.content: Canada based journalist Joanna Chiu on Monday saved a teenage girl from a man who leaned on her and asked for a "dirty" photo on a flight. Chiu intervened and informed a flight attendant and the man was moved to another seat after being threatened of immediate landing. When the flight landed, the airline gave the journalist a thank you note.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Feel sickened having my name uttered by NZ terrorist: PewDiePie
data.content: YouTuber Felix Kjellberg, who runs the most subscribed channel PewDiePie, said he's "absolutely sickened" to learn his name was uttered by the Christchurch terrorist shortly before the attack. The man who filmed himself shooting victims at a mosque encouraged viewers to "subscribe to PewDiePie" in a video livestream. An 87 page manifesto allegedly written by the terrorist was posted online.
data.author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

data.title: London HIV patient second in the world to be cleared of AIDS virus
data.content: A man dubbed 'London patient' has become the second known adult worldwide to be cleared of HIV, three years after he received a bone marrow transplant from a virus resistant donor. The donor had a genetic mutation 'CCR5 delta 32', which gives HIV resistance. The patient is "functionally cured but it's too early to say he's cured," said Dr Ravindra Gupta.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Trump's ex-campaign worker sues him for forcibly kissing her in 2016
data.content: Alva Johnson, a former staffer on Donald Trump's presidential campaign has filed a federal lawsuit against the president, claiming he kissed her without consent in 2016. "I...felt violated because I wasn't expecting it or wanting it," said Johnson. The lawsuit also alleges the campaign discriminated against Johnson, who is black, by paying her less than her white male counterparts.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Bangladesh plane 'hijacker' allegedly had affair with local film star
data.content: The 25 year old man suspected of trying to hijack Biman Bangladesh Airlines' Dubai bound flight on Sunday had an affair with a local film star, his father alleged. Intimate images, believed to be of the pair, have gone viral on social media since the incident, reports said. However, an official said the hijacker had said he had issues with his wife.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Suspected Dubai-bound plane hijacker shot dead: Bangladesh Army
data.content: Bangladesh Army has said the suspect who tried to hijack the Biman Bangladesh Airlines flight en route Dubai from Dhaka got injured after being shot at and died shortly after being arrested on Sunday. "He demanded to speak to our prime minister," Air Vice Marshal Mofid said. Bangladesh's civil aviation chief, Nayeem Hasan, said he seemed to be "psychologically deranged".
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: World food supply under threat from loss of biodiversity: UN
data.content: The world's food supplies are under "severe threat" due to the rapid decline in the number of animal and plant species, the UN's Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) said. Of the 6,000 plant species cultivated for food, just nine species account for 66% of total crop production. The loss in biodiversity was attributed to over harvesting and climate change, among others.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ebola vaccine offered in return for sex in Congo: Reports
data.content: Women in the Democratic Republic of Congo are being asked for sexual favours in return for Ebola related services such as vaccinations, several studies quoting respondents claimed. The reports further said there was a rise in stigma and violence targetting women following the latest Ebola outbreak. Women working on the Ebola response were reportedly given jobs in exchange for sexual favours.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Reporting on Bezos' affair legal, says tabloid accused of blackmail
data.content: National Enquirer tabloid's owner AMI on Friday said it acted "lawfully" in reporting on world's richest person Jeff Bezos' affair with ex TV host Lauren Sanchez. AMI added it will "investigate" allegations of extortion made by Bezos. Bezos had alleged AMI wanted him to drop an investigation into how it obtained his private messages by threatening to leak his nude pictures.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: Uganda minister suggests 'using curvy women' to attract tourists
data.content: Uganda's tourism minister Godfrey Kiwanda has suggested showcasing the country's curvy women to attract more tourists. Kiwanda launched the 'Miss Curvy Uganda' beauty pageant, with the finalists to be selected in June, as part of a campaign to attract foreign visitors. The tourism ministry also proposed to add "sexy and curvy women" to Uganda's list of tourist attractions.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Pope admits nuns kept as sex slaves by priests
data.content: Pope Francis for the first time admitted to sexual abuse of nuns by Catholic priests and bishops, including sexual slavery. He added that his  predecessor, Pope Benedict XVI, shut down an entire congregation of nuns who were being abused by priests. His remarks came after a magazine claimed that in some cases nuns were forced to abort priests' children.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Nobel winner Arias accused of assault by 4 women in 48 hrs
data.content: Nobel Peace Prize winner and former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias has been accused of assault by four women in 48 hours. A nuclear disarmament activist was the first to accuse Arias, claiming he assaulted her at his home in 2014. Arias received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1987 for his efforts to end the civil wars in Central America.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Swedish guards drag 8-month pregnant woman out of train over ticket
data.content: A video showing a woman, believed to be 8 months pregnant, being dragged out of the Stockholm metro by two guards has surfaced online. The woman, who was with her daughter, was caught without a ticket, officials said. She was later rushed to hospital for treatment and the two guards have been suspended pending an inquiry.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Tokyo Metro offers early commuters free food to help ease congestion
data.content: In order to help ease passenger flow during rush hours, the Tokyo Metro service is offering free food coupons to early morning passengers on Tozai Line to convince more people to travel at different timings. Launched on Monday, the offer will continue on weekdays until February 1. During 7:50 am to 8:50 am, over 76,000 passengers use the Tozai Line.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: 2-yr-old walks toward police with her hands up as dad gets arrested
data.content: A video showing a barefoot two year old girl getting out of a vehicle and walking toward police officers with her hands up as her father gets arrested has gone viral. "You're okay, come over here sweetie, you're okay. Put your hands down, you're fine," a police officer can be heard saying to the girl. The father was later charged with theft.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: World's oldest man Masazo Nonaka dies in Japan aged 113
data.content: Masazo Nonaka, who was recognised as the world's oldest man by Guinness World Records last year, has passed away at the age of 113. His family said Nonaka died peacefully from natural causes in the early hours of Sunday while sleeping. Nonaka, who enjoyed watching sumo wrestling and eating sweets, outlived his wife and three of their five children.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: World's 26 richest people hold as much wealth as poorest 50%: Oxfam
data.content: The world's richest 26 people hold as much wealth as the 380 crore people who make up the poorest half of world's population, a report by charity group Oxfam has revealed. Oxfam said 2018 had been a year in which the rich had grown richer and the poor poorer. It said the widening gap was hindering the fight against poverty.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 1 in 3 UN employees sexually harassed in past two years
data.content: One third of United Nations (UN) employees have been sexually harassed at work in the past two years, according to the findings of the first survey on such misconduct.  Out of the 30,364 respondents, 10.1% said that they were touched in ways that made them feel uncomfortable. Only one in three people said that they took action after experiencing sexual harassment.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Chinese pilot suspended, fined ₹1 lakh for allowing wife in cockpit
data.content: A pilot with Donghai Airlines has been suspended for 6 months and fined over ₹1 lakh for allowing his wife to enter the cockpit. According to the airline, the pilot had let his wife into the cockpit on two flights last year. The pilot, who had not bought full tickets, has also been ordered to pay for his wife's journey.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Sri Lanka struggling to pay foreign debt of $5.9 billion: PM
data.content: Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said that his government is struggling to pay the record foreign debt of $5.9 billion this year. Wickremesinghe blamed the political crisis last year which was triggered by his ouster, for dealing "a death blow to an economy that was struggling to recover". Sri Lanka lost $1 billion in foreign reserves in 2018.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Pak PM Sharif denied help, told to maintain jail room on his own
data.content: Ex Pakistan PM Nawaz Sharif has been denied a prisoner who could serve as his orderly and told to maintain his room on his own. Officials said Sharif's case was highly sensitive and he could not be allowed to go outside his barracks in the prison. Sharif is currently serving a seven year jail term in the Al Azizia Steel Mills corruption case.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: B'desh captain Mortaza becomes MP, wins election by 2,66,412 votes
data.content: Bangladesh ODI captain Mashrafe Mortaza has become a member of parliament after winning from the Narail 2 constituency in the country's 11th general elections. The 35 year old, who contested on a ticket from Sheikh Hasina led Awami League party, received 2,74,418 votes, while his nearest competitor got 8,006 votes. Mortaza is said to be the first active cricketer to become an MP.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: 3G, 4G services suspended in Bangladesh ahead of elections
data.content: Bangladesh slowed down Internet services across the country and suspended 3G and 4G services for 10 hours to "prevent propaganda and misleading content spreading on the Internet" ahead of the general elections, an official said. The Bangladesh Telecommunication Regulatory Commission had earlier blocked the website of the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party along with over 50 news websites.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Over 5,000 people killed in Philippine President's drug war
data.content: The death toll in the Philippines due to the war on drugs initiated by President Rodrigo Duterte has risen above 5,000. The authorities said that at least 5,050 people have lost their lives since the drug war began after Duterte became the President in 2016. Duterte is being investigated for allegedly committing crimes against humanity in the anti drugs war.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Wickremesinghe reinstated as Sri Lanka PM 51 days after being sacked
data.content: Ranil Wickremesinghe was reinstated as Sri Lanka's Prime Minister on Sunday, 51 days after he was sacked by President Maithripala Sirisena. This comes a day after Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was appointed as the PM by Sirisena following Wickremesinghe's ouster, resigned from the post. Wickremesinghe was sacked by Sirisena following differences over policy making and other issues.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sri Lanka's sacked PM Wickremesinghe wins confidence vote
data.content: Ousted Sri Lankan Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe won a confidence vote in the Parliament on Wednesday. Sri Lanka has been embroiled in a political crisis since President Maithripala Sirisena sacked Wickremesinghe in October and replaced him with Mahinda Rajapaksa. Rajapaksa, the former Sri Lankan President, has refused to resign despite two no confidence votes being passed against him.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Dissolution of Sri Lanka Parliament by Prez illegal, rules SC
data.content: Sri Lanka's Supreme Court has called the Parliament's dissolution by President Maithripala Sirisena illegal. Sirisena dissolved the Parliament in November after his party announced it lacked the majority to secure support for PM Mahinda Rajapaksa. The seven member bench unanimously ruled that President cannot dissolve parliament until it completes four and a half years out of its five year term.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: More than half the world will be online by year end: UN
data.content: The UN agency for information and communication technologies, ITU, has said that 51.2% of the world's population or 3.9 billion people will be using the Internet by the end of 2018. Developing nations went from 7.7% Internet use in 2005 to 45.3% in 2018. ITU added that 96% of the world's population is within the reach of a cellular network.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-US beauty contest winner arrested for sending nudes to 15-yr-old
data.content: Former Miss Kentucky Ramsey Bearse, the 28 year old pageant winner working as a science teacher at a school, has been arrested for sending her nude pictures to a 15 year old former student. The student's parents informed the police after finding Bearse's nude photos on their teenage son's phone. Authorities say Bearse admitted to sending the nude photos on Snapchat.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Qatar to withdraw from OPEC after nearly 60 years
data.content: Qatar will withdraw from the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in January after nearly 60 years, country's energy minister Saad al Kaabi said. The decision to withdraw from OPEC came after Qatar reviewed ways to enhance its role internationally and plan its long term strategy. Qatar is one of OPEC's smallest producers but the world's largest liquefied natural gas exporter.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sri Lanka court blocks Rajapaksa from acting as PM
data.content: A Sri Lankan court has issued an order blocking Mahinda Rajapaksa from acting as Prime Minister and holding cabinet meetings. The court was hearing a petition signed by 122 legislators that challenged Rajapaksa's authority to hold office after he lost two no confidence votes last month. Rajapaksa was appointed by President Maithripala Sirisena after he sacked Ranil Wickremesinghe as PM.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sri Lanka Parliament blocks ministers' salaries to pressure PM
data.content: The Sri Lankan Parliament has voted to block the salaries and travel expenses of ministers with an aim to exert pressure on Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa. Rajapaksa has refused to step down despite losing two no confidence votes. Former PM Ranil Wickremesinghe who was sacked by President Maithripala Sirisena commands a majority in Parliament.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Won't reappoint sacked PM in my lifetime: Sri Lanka Prez
data.content: Sri Lanka President Maithripala Sirisena on Sunday said that he will not reappoint sacked PM Ranil Wickremesinghe in his lifetime even if Wickremesinghe proves majority in parliament. Sirisena added that he sacked Wickremesinghe because of policy differences and rise in corruption. Wickremesinghe was sacked last month and replaced by former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Home 'most dangerous place' for women: UN study
data.content: A new UN study on Sunday said more than half the women who were murdered worldwide last year were killed by their partners or family members, making home "the most dangerous place for women". "...women continue to be affected by...violence to...greater degree than men is indicative of an imbalance in power relations between women and men inside...domestic sphere", UN said.
data.author: Shashank Verma

data.title: 14-yr-old 'Stranger Things' actress named youngest UNICEF envoy
data.content: Millie Bobby Brown, who stars in the Netflix series 'Stranger Things', has been named as the UNICEF's youngest ever Goodwill Ambassador. The 14 year old actress said that she will use the platform to highlight children's rights and issues. "(T)o be the youngest ever Goodwill Ambassador for UNICEF is more than an honour. It's a powerful privilege," the actress said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN General Assembly adopts 1st resolution on sexual harassment
data.content: The Third Committee of the United Nations General Assembly on Monday adopted the world body's first resolution to combat sexual harassment. The resolution urges countries to address the discrimination faced by women that makes them vulnerable to exploitation, violence and abuse. It also encourages states to adopt measures to eliminate violence and sexual harassment in digital contexts.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN environment head resigns after frequent flying criticism
data.content: The United Nations Environment Programme's Executive Director, Erik Solheim, has resigned following criticism for extensive air travels. A draft internal UN audit had found that Solheim had spent nearly ₹3.5 crore on air travels and hotels while travelling for 529 out of 668 days. Solheim's air travels were seen as contrary to the efforts to reduce carbon emissions.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: White House restores CNN journalist's press pass
data.content: The White House has restored CNN reporter Jim Acosta's press pass, which was revoked after he had an angry exchange with President Donald Trump during a news conference. The White House also issued "rules governing future press conferences", warning that further action against Acosta will be taken unless he follows the new rules.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sri Lankan lawmakers fight in parliament, dustbin thrown at Speaker
data.content: The Sri Lankan lawmakers engaged in a fight in the Parliament on Thursday over the ongoing argument regarding disputed PM Mahinda Rajapaksa, with one them throwing a dustbin at Speaker Karu Jayasuriya. Earlier on Wednesday, the chamber passed a no confidence vote against Rajapaksa's government. Rajapaksa claimed the speaker had no authority to remove him from office by voice vote.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Sri Lankan MPs pass no-confidence motion against Rajapaksa
data.content: The Sri Lankan Parliament on Wednesday passed a no confidence motion against the government headed by Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, effectively removing the leader and his cabinet from their posts. The Parliament was meeting for the first time since October 26, when President Maithripala Sirisena sacked Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and appointed former President Rajapaksa in his place.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: Sri Lanka top court overturns prez order to sack parliament
data.content: Sri Lanka's Supreme Court has overruled President Maithripala Sirisena's dissolution of parliament and ordered a halt to preparations for snap elections on January 5, 2019. Sirisena had earlier sacked PM Ranil Wickremesinghe and replaced him with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa. Wickremesinghe said he'll prove his majority in the parliament, which should open on Wednesday.
data.author: Aarushi Maheshwari

data.title: SL PM defects from party led by Prez who installed him in office
data.content: Sri Lanka's new PM Mahinda Rajapaksa has defected from the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), led by President Maithripala Sirisena, who installed him in office. This comes after Sirisena dissolved the parliament and called a general election for January 5. Sirisena previously defected from SLFP, then led by Rajapaksa, in 2014 to join an opposition coalition that ousted Rajapaksa.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: India-Morocco sign pact for assistance in criminal matters
data.content: Minister of State for Home Affairs Kiren Rijiju and Morocco's Minister of Justice Mohamed Aujjar on Monday signed an agreement on Mutual Legal Assistance in criminal matters. The pact will provide a broad legal framework for prevention, investigation and prosecution of crimes, the government said. It will help in "tracing, restraint and confiscation of funds meant to finance terrorist acts".
data.author: Ayushi Ahluwalia

data.title: Sri Lanka President dissolves Parliament amid political crisis
data.content: Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena dissolved the Parliament on Friday after his party announced that it did not have the majority to secure support for PM Mahinda Rajapaksa. Sirisena called for snap parliamentary elections on January 5, nearly two years ahead of schedule. Sri Lankan Parliament's Speaker, Karu Jayasuriya, had refused to recognise Rajapaksa as PM until he proved majority.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Sri Lanka suffered coup without guns: Speaker on PM's sacking
data.content: Karu Jayasuriya, the Speaker of Sri Lankan Parliament has compared the sacking of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe by President Maithripala Sirisena to a coup, albeit one without the use of tanks and guns. Jayasuriya also claimed that the "entire matter was pre planned". Jayasuriya has refused to recognise Mahinda Rajapaksa as Prime Minister until he proves a majority in the Parliament.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US passenger forced to sit on faeces-covered seat on flight
data.content: A Delta Air Lines passenger was forced to sit on a faeces covered seat after flight crew refused to clean the excrement he found in his seat upon boarding. He alleged that the crew, instead of cleaning it themselves gave him paper towels and a bottle of gin from the drink cart, and told him to clean himself in the lavatory.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Won't accept Rajapaksa as PM until he proves majority: SL Speaker
data.content: Karu Jayasuriya, the Speaker of Sri Lankan Parliament has said that he will not recognise Mahinda Rajapaksa as the Prime Minister until he proves majority in the Parliament. President Maithripala Sirisena had removed Ranil Wickremesinghe from the post of the Prime Minister and replaced him with Rajapaksa. Several parliamentarians have termed Sirisena's move unconstitutional, Jayasuriya added.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I'm still Prime Minister: Sri Lanka's sacked PM Wickremesinghe
data.content: Sri Lanka's sacked Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has said that he commands the majority in the Parliament and is still the PM. Wickremesinghe, who was sacked by Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena last week, called the move illegal. Wickremesinghe added that he will not leave office unless he fails a floor test.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Bangladesh court doubles ex-PM Khaleda Zia's 5-year jail term
data.content: A Bangladesh court has doubled ex PM Khaleda Zia's 5 year jail term handed over to her in a corruption case in February 2018. Zia, who claimed the case was politically motivated, was found guilty of embezzling 21 million taka (₹1.8 crore) meant for an orphanage. The decision comes a day after Zia was jailed for seven years in a separate case.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: New Sri Lankan cabinet sworn in amid political crisis
data.content: Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena swore in a new cabinet on Monday amid the political crisis in the island nation. Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was appointed as the Prime Minister after Sirisena sacked Ranil Wickremesinghe, got the Finance and Economic Affairs portfolio. A total of 12 new Cabinet Ministers, one State Minister and a Deputy Minister were sworn in.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Former B'desh PM Khaleda Zia jailed for 7 years in corruption case
data.content: A Bangladesh court on Monday sentenced former Prime Minister Khaleda Zia to seven years in jail on corruption charges. Zia was found guilty of corruption charges linked to the misappropriation of ₹2.7 crore set aside for the Zia Charitable Trust Fund. In February, another court sentenced her to five years in jail for embezzling ₹1.8 crore meant for an orphanage.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 1 dead, 2 injured after ex-SL minister Arjuna's guard opens fire
data.content: One person died and two others were injured after sacked Sri Lanka Petroleum Minister Arjuna Ranatunga's guard opened fire while reportedly preventing a mob's attempt to take the politician hostage. The incident happened while Ranatunga was trying to enter his office at the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation. Ranatunga was a minister in the Cabinet dissolved by President Maithripala Sirisena on Saturday.
data.author: Anmol Sharma

data.title: Sri Lanka President suspends parliament day after sacking PM
data.content: Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena on Saturday suspended the country's parliament, a day after he sacked Ranil Wickremesinghe as Prime Minister and replaced him with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa. Sirisena's move comes after Wickremesinghe, who claimed he remains Prime Minister, asked the Speaker to convene the parliament on Sunday to prove he still retained his parliamentary majority.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Wickremesinghe recognised as Sri Lanka PM three days after sacking
data.content: Sri Lankan Parliament's Speaker Karu Jayasuriya has recognised Ranil Wickremesinghe as the country's lawful PM, three days after his sacking by President Maithripala Sirisena. Jayasuriya said Wickremesinghe's request to retain the security and privileges of PM was fair until another candidate could prove a majority in Parliament. Sirisena had appointed ex President Mahinda Rajapaksa as new PM.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Sri Lanka Prez sacks PM, replaces him with ex-Prez Rajapaksa
data.content: Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena on Friday sacked Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and replaced him with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa. Sirisena sacked Wickremesinghe following months of tension between the two leaders that led to a political crisis. This came as Sirisena's United People's Freedom Alliance withdrew from the coalition government, the local media reported.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Climate change intensifying world conflicts: Red Cross
data.content: Climate change is intensifying domestic and international conflicts, President of the International Committee of the Red Cross, Peter Maurer has said. Climate change and changing rainfall patterns are affecting the movement of people and the fertility of the land, he added. "When (people) migrate in big numbers it leads to tensions between migrating and local communities," he further said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Maldives SC upholds President Yameen's poll defeat
data.content: The Maldives' Supreme Court has upheld the result of the presidential election where President Abdulla Yameen lost to opposition candidate Ibrahim Mohamed Solih. The court rejected Yameen's petition seeking annulment of the result, ruling that Yameen had failed to prove that the elections were rigged. He had initially conceded defeat but called for fresh elections later citing unfair elections.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Remains of over 60 babies, foetuses found at US funeral home
data.content: The remains of over 60 infants and foetuses were found at a Detroit funeral home, police said on Friday, calling the discovery "deeply disturbing". The incident comes about a week after decomposed bodies of 11 babies were found in a false ceiling at another funeral home in the Michigan city. However, a link between the cases was not yet established.
data.author: Gaurav Shroff

data.title: F*CK you all: Google exec tells Republicans in deleted tweet
data.content: A senior Google designer, Dave Hogue, criticised the Republicans on Twitter over the appointment of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court, saying, "F*** you all to hell". He later admitted to deleting the tweet, adding, "Yes, those opinions are mine personally, and I am responsible for them." Judge Brett Kavanaugh had publicly been accused of sexual assaults by three women.
data.author: Mahi Chauhan

data.title: Pope says abortion is like hiring 'contract killer'
data.content: Pope Francis on Wednesday compared having an abortion to hiring a "contract killer". "Interrupting a pregnancy is like eliminating someone...Getting rid of a human being is like resorting to a contract killer to solve a problem," he said. Further, the pontiff questioned that how can an "act that suppresses innocent life be therapeutic".
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 50 killed, 100 suffer burns in oil tanker crash in Congo
data.content: Around 50 people were killed and 100 others suffered second degree burns after an oil tanker caught fire in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Saturday, officials said. The accident occurred as the tanker collided with a vehicle on a highway in western Congo. "(T)he flames spread rapidly engulfing nearby houses," the UN's radio network in Congo said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Hid a patch of dress from 1st date in my wedding dress: Meghan
data.content: The Duchess of Sussex Meghan Markle has revealed she got a piece of fabric from her dress worn at first blind date with Prince Harry stitched into her wedding dress. She also revealed she saw her veil for the first time on her wedding day. Markle and Prince Harry were set up on a blind date by Ralph Lauren publicist.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Would launch military weapons to defend US: SpaceX President
data.content: On being asked if SpaceX would launch military weapons, the startup's President Gwynne Shotwell has said, "If it's for the defense of this country, yes, I think we would." She further said that SpaceX spent a lot of time building its relationship with the Air Force. The "most challenging" government customer for SpaceX has been NASA, she added.
data.author: Shifa Naseer

data.title: Thousands turn out to vote in Maldives presidential election
data.content: Thousands of people on Sunday turned out to vote in the Maldives' presidential election, with voting being extended for three hours due to long queues. Several countries have requested the Maldives to conduct the election in a free and fair manner. The Maldives has been facing a political crisis since a 45 day state of emergency was imposed in February.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UN environment chief criticised for frequent flying
data.content: The United Nations Environment Programme's Executive Director, Erik Solheim, has been criticised for extensive air travels which are "contrary to the ethos of carbon emission reduction", a draft internal audit said. Over ₹3.5 crore was spent while Solheim travelled for 529 out of the 668 audited days. The report said Solheim had "no regard for abiding by regulations and rules".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Bhutan PM carries wife on back to not dirty her feet, pic viral
data.content: Ex Bhutan PM Tshering Tobgay posted a picture of himself carrying his wife on a muddy road to prevent her from dirtying her feet, saying, "A man's gotta do what a man's gotta do." Tobgay said he wasn't as "dashing" as Sir Walter Raleigh, who apparently laid his cloak over a puddle to keep Queen Elizabeth I from dirtying her feet.
data.author: Saloni Tandon

data.title: Nuts offered by airline weren't even fit for dogs: SL Prez
data.content: Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena has said that during a recent trip with SriLankan Airlines, he was treated to some cashew nuts which were not even suitable for dogs. "Who approved the cashews? Who is responsible for this?" Sirisena asked. Following this, the airline said it has cleared its stock of cashews, adding that it would change its Dubai based supplier.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UN Security Council holds first-ever meeting on corruption
data.content: The UN Security Council (UNSC) on Monday held its first ever meeting on corruption and its linkages to global conflicts. UN Secretary General António Guterres said that corruption is linked to illicit trafficking of arms, drugs and people as well as terrorism. Citing the World Economic Forum's estimates, he added that corruption costs at least $2.6 trillion or 5% of global GDP.
data.author: Nandini Sinha
